content: 3 pattern notes the specified cast-on method creates a monolithic brim uninterrupted by the horizontal edge of traditional cast-on methods if you substitute methods select a very stretchy one the foundation row after the tubular cast-on are worked flat before joining in the round use the tail to close the seam when finishing if using a 16 circular needle place a stitch marker to indicate the beginning of round when you join if using magic loop or dpns you may choose to leave your end of round at the gap between needles or work a few stitches onto a needle to keep the stitch marker in place while working the ribbed brim increase your gauge as you bring the yarn forward to purl the ribbing should be dense and elastic and can be tried on for fit before beginning the braid latvian braid twists the working yarn in one direction during round 2 and the other direction during round 3 in smaller projects the yarn can be allowed to twist without correcting it but in patterns with high stitch counts you will need to stop partway through the rounds to untwist the yarn work rounds 2 and 3 fairly loosely to allow braid to stretch when worn after establishing latvian braid color sequence in round 1 all cc stitches in rounds 2 and 3 will be worked into a cc stitch and all mc stitches will be worked into an mc stitch alternate chart d is provided on page 11 as a simplified option by test knitter mugginsquilts work the stranded portion loosely stretching as you go to ensure the floats are long enough to allow the entire hat to stretch when worn if you see puckering or notice that your fabric doesn t stretch place a lifeline in the plain stockinette round before the stranded portion and rip back to your lifeline ease cannot be added back into colorwork that is too tight trap floats longer than four stitches at staggered intervals to avoid making columns of trapped floats that show through on the right side this type of stranded knitting benefits from deliberate creation of yarn dominance hold cc to the left of mc to give the cc stitches more slack stranded knitting should be blocked to block wool and other natural fibers soak in tepid water for half an hour press out the water roll in a towel to remove more water then smooth out gently on a flat surface to dry alternately steam-block by placing a clean damp cotton or linen napkin tea towel or receiving blanket on the hat body and lightly pressing with a steam iron or using a clothes steamer do not steam-block the ribbing to block acrylic place a clean damp cotton or linen napkin tea towel or receiving blanket on the hat body and hold a steam iron or clothes steamer just above the cloth do not make contact with the hat do not block the ribbing rock step slouch by
